title: Setting Up Hypotheses
description: A manufacturer claims their light bulbs last an average of 1000 hours. You suspect they last less. Set up the null and alternative hypotheses.
hints: Hₐ reflects what you're trying to show
solution:
H₀: μ = 1000 (manufacturer's claim)
Hₐ: μ < 1000 (our suspicion)

This is a one-tailed (left-tailed) test.

title: Type I and Type II Errors
description: In a criminal trial, H₀ is "defendant is innocent". Describe Type I and Type II errors in this context and their consequences.
hints: Type II: Fail to reject false H₀
solution:
Type I Error:
- Reject H₀ when it's true
- Convict an innocent person
- Consequence: Injustice to innocent defendant
- Probability: α (significance level)

Type II Error:
- Fail to reject H₀ when it's false
- Acquit a guilty person
- Consequence: Guilty person goes free
- Probability: β

Legal system is designed to minimize Type I error ("innocent until proven guilty"), accepting higher Type II error risk.

title: One-Sample Z-Test
description: A sample of 36 observations has mean 52. Population standard deviation is known to be σ=12. Test H₀: μ=50 vs Hₐ: μ≠50 at α=0.05.
solution:
Given: n=36, x̄=52, σ=12, μ₀=50, α=0.05

Test statistic:
z = (52 - 50)/(12/√36) = 2/(12/6) = 2/2 = 1

Critical values (two-tailed): ±1.96

Decision: |z| = 1 < 1.96, so fail to reject H₀

Conclusion: Insufficient evidence to conclude μ ≠ 50 at α=0.05 level.

P-value ≈ 2×P(Z>1) = 2(0.1587) = 0.317

title: One-Sample t-Test
description: A sample of n=16 has x̄=75 and s=8. Test H₀: μ=70 vs Hₐ: μ>70 at α=0.05. (Use t₀.₀₅,₁₅ ≈ 1.753)
solution:
Given: n=16, x̄=75, s=8, μ₀=70, α=0.05

Test statistic:
t = (75 - 70)/(8/√16) = 5/(8/4) = 5/2 = 2.5

Critical value (one-tailed, df=15): t₀.₀₅,₁₅ = 1.753

Decision: t = 2.5 > 1.753, so reject H₀

Conclusion: Significant evidence that μ > 70 at α=0.05 level.

title: Two-Sample t-Test
description: Group 1: n₁=20, x̄₁=85, s₁=10. Group 2: n₂=25, x̄₂=80, s₂=12. Test if the means differ at α=0.05. Assume equal variances.
solution:
Pooled variance:
s²ₚ = [(19)(100) + (24)(144)]/43
= [1900 + 3456]/43 = 5356/43 ≈ 124.56

Standard error:
SE = √[124.56(1/20 + 1/25)] = √[124.56(0.09)] = √11.21 ≈ 3.35

Test statistic:
t = (85 - 80)/3.35 = 5/3.35 ≈ 1.49

Critical value (two-tailed, df≈43): t₀.₀₂₅ ≈ 2.02

Decision: |t| = 1.49 < 2.02, fail to reject H₀

Conclusion: Insufficient evidence that means differ at α=0.05.

title: Paired t-Test
description: Before/after measurements for 8 subjects: differences = {2, 5, 3, 4, 6, 1, 3, 4}. Test if there's a significant improvement at α=0.05.
hints: Calculate mean and SD of differences
Test H₀: μd=0 vs Hₐ: μd>0
solution:
Differences: {2, 5, 3, 4, 6, 1, 3, 4}

Mean: d̄ = (2+5+3+4+6+1+3+4)/8 = 28/8 = 3.5

SD: sd = √[Σ(di - d̄)²/7]
= √[(2.25+2.25+0.25+0.25+6.25+6.25+0.25+0.25)/7]
= √[18/7] ≈ 1.60

Test statistic:
t = 3.5/(1.60/√8) = 3.5/0.566 ≈ 6.19

Critical value (one-tailed, df=7): t₀.₀₅,₇ ≈ 1.895

Decision: t = 6.19 > 1.895, reject H₀

Conclusion: Significant evidence of improvement.

title: Test for Proportion
description: A company claims 90% customer satisfaction. In a sample of 200, 170 were satisfied. Test the claim at α=0.05.
solution:
Given: n=200, x=170, p₀=0.90
p̂ = 170/200 = 0.85

Test statistic:
z = (0.85 - 0.90)/√[0.90(0.10)/200]
= -0.05/√0.00045
= -0.05/0.0212 ≈ -2.36

Critical values (two-tailed): ±1.96

Decision: |z| = 2.36 > 1.96, reject H₀

Conclusion: Significant evidence that satisfaction rate ≠ 90%. The actual rate appears lower.

title: Chi-Square Goodness of Fit
description: A die is rolled 60 times with outcomes: {1:8, 2:12, 3:9, 4:11, 5:10, 6:10}. Test if the die is fair at α=0.05.
solution:
H₀: Die is fair (all probabilities = 1/6)
Expected frequency: E = 60/6 = 10 for each outcome

χ² = (8-10)²/10 + (12-10)²/10 + (9-10)²/10 + (11-10)²/10 + (10-10)²/10 + (10-10)²/10
= 4/10 + 4/10 + 1/10 + 1/10 + 0 + 0
= 10/10 = 1.0

Critical value (df=5, α=0.05): χ²₀.₀₅,₅ ≈ 11.07

Decision: χ² = 1.0 < 11.07, fail to reject H₀

Conclusion: No evidence that die is unfair.

title: Chi-Square Test of Independence
description:
Test if smoking and lung disease are independent:
             Disease  No Disease
Smoker         20        30
Non-smoker     10        40
Use α=0.05.
hints: Calculate expected frequencies: E = (row total × column total)/grand total
solution:
Row totals: 50, 50. Column totals: 30, 70. Grand total: 100

Expected frequencies:
E₁₁ = (50×30)/100 = 15
E₁₂ = (50×70)/100 = 35
E₂₁ = (50×30)/100 = 15
E₂₂ = (50×70)/100 = 35

χ² = (20-15)²/15 + (30-35)²/35 + (10-15)²/15 + (40-35)²/35
= 25/15 + 25/35 + 25/15 + 25/35
= 1.667 + 0.714 + 1.667 + 0.714 = 4.762

Critical value (df=1, α=0.05): χ²₀.₀₅,₁ = 3.84

Decision: χ² = 4.762 > 3.84, reject H₀

Conclusion: Significant evidence that smoking and lung disease are not independent.

title: ANOVA F-Test
description: Three groups have: Group 1: n₁=5, x̄₁=10, s₁²=4; Group 2: n₂=5, x̄₂=12, s₂²=5; Group 3: n₃=5, x̄₃=15, s₃²=6. Test if means differ at α=0.05.

title: p-Value Interpretation
description: A test yields p-value = 0.03. Interpret this for α = 0.05 and α = 0.01.
hints: Smaller p-value means stronger evidence against H₀
solution:
p-value = 0.03 means:
"If H₀ were true, the probability of observing data as extreme as ours is 0.03 or 3%"

For α = 0.05:
p = 0.03 < 0.05, so reject H₀
Result is statistically significant at the 5% level.

For α = 0.01:
p = 0.03 > 0.01, so fail to reject H₀
Result is NOT statistically significant at the 1% level.

Conclusion: We have moderate evidence against H₀, significant at 5% but not at 1% level.

title: Statistical vs Practical Significance
description: A drug lowers blood pressure by an average of 0.5 mmHg with p < 0.001 in a study of 10,000 patients. Discuss statistical vs practical significance.
hints: Consider effect size vs sample size
solution:
Statistical significance:
p < 0.001 is highly statistically significant
With n=10,000, we have very high power to detect even tiny effects
We're very confident the effect is real (not due to chance)

Practical significance:
0.5 mmHg reduction is clinically trivial
Normal blood pressure variation is much larger
This effect has minimal health impact

Conclusion: The result is statistically significant but NOT practically significant. Large samples can detect tiny effects that have no practical importance. Always consider effect size, not just p-value.

title: Power of a Test
description: Define statistical power. What factors increase the power of a hypothesis test?
hints: Consider sample size, effect size, significance level
solution:
Statistical Power:
Power = P(Reject H₀ | H₀ is false) = 1 - β
Probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis
Probability of detecting a real effect

Factors that INCREASE power:
1. Larger sample size (n↑)
2. Larger effect size (true difference from H₀)
3. Higher significance level (α↑, but increases Type I error)
4. Lower population variance (σ²↓)
5. One-tailed vs two-tailed test (if direction is known)

Typical target: Power ≥ 0.80 (80% chance of detecting effect if it exists)

title: Power Calculation
description: For testing H₀: μ=50 vs Hₐ: μ>50 with σ=10, n=25, α=0.05, calculate the power if the true mean is μ=54.
hints: Find critical value for x̄ under H₀
Calculate probability of exceeding this under true μ=54
solution:
Under H₀: μ₀=50, σx̄ = 10/√25 = 2
Critical value: z = 1.645
x̄c = 50 + 1.645(2) = 53.29

Under true μ=54:
z = (53.29 - 54)/2 = -0.355

Power = P(x̄ > 53.29 | μ=54)
= P(Z > -0.355)
= 1 - P(Z < -0.355)
≈ 1 - 0.361 = 0.639 or 63.9%

There's about 64% chance of detecting the difference if μ=54.

title: Multiple Testing Problem
description: Explain the multiple testing problem. If you conduct 20 independent tests at α=0.05, what is the probability of at least one Type I error?
hints: Each test has 5% chance of Type I error
solution:
Multiple Testing Problem:
When conducting multiple hypothesis tests, the probability of at least one Type I error increases.

For 20 independent tests at α=0.05:
P(no Type I errors) = (1-0.05)^20 = (0.95)^20 ≈ 0.358
P(at least one Type I error) = 1 - 0.358 = 0.642

About 64% chance of at least one false positive!

Solutions:
1. Bonferroni correction: Use α/k for each test
2. False Discovery Rate control
3. Adjust significance level
4. Plan analyses in advance, limit exploratory testing

This is why "p-hacking" (testing many hypotheses until finding p<0.05) is problematic.

title: Effect Size Measures
description: For comparing two means, explain Cohen's d as an effect size measure. Why is it useful beyond just reporting p-values?
solution:
Cohen's d = (μ₁ - μ₂)/σ or (x̄₁ - x̄₂)/s_pooled

Interpretation (rough guidelines):
d ≈ 0.2: Small effect
d ≈ 0.5: Medium effect
d ≈ 0.8: Large effect

Why useful:
1. Independent of sample size (unlike p-values)
2. Standardized, allowing comparison across studies
3. Indicates practical significance, not just statistical
4. Example: d=0.2 with p<0.001 (large n) vs d=0.8 with p=0.06 (small n)
   Second has larger effect despite not being "significant"

Always report effect sizes with p-values for complete interpretation.
